bioghist.p: John Davison (1930-1999) was a composer-pianist who studied at Juilliard, Haverford College, Harvard, and Eastman. Among his teachers were Alfred Swan, Randall Thompson, Walter Piston, Bernard Rogers, Howard Hanson, Alan Hovhaness, and Robert Palmer. Davison taught at Haverford College from 1959 until his death. His music was published and recorded and has been played widely in the United States, as well as in Europe and Asia. He wrote for most of the standard media, as well as for unusual instruments such as koto, cimbalom, and bagpipe. Davison's idiom was rooted in the great Western classic-romantic tradition with Baroque, Renaissance, jazz, modernist, and folk elements mixing in at times.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional and personal papers of John Davison. Included are musical scores, student compositions, personal and professional correspondence (1938-1999), and audio tapes. The collection also includes a sketchbook and several concert notices. Correspondents include Randall Thompson, A. Swan, Howard Hanson, Archibald Davison and others.
